characters: STAY AWAY FROM MY WIFE OR I WILL PUNCH HIM."
SAY. HOWEVER, I THINK HE MAY BE MISLEADING YOU."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OMINOUS, THREATENING MUSIC. The upper tail fin of a jet plane emerges through the cloud layer and PASSES THROUGH FRAME like a shark's fin through water. It passes by agai in the opposite direction. MUSIC BUILDS as the fin comes straight TOWARD the CAMERA, MUSIC SWELLS to CRESCENDO as entire jet plane lifts out of clouds and passes overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CREDITS and MUSIC continue over following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING terminal building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Airport bus arrives. Stewardess ELAINE DICKINSON steps of CAMERA FOLLOWS Elaine as she walks to terminal building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (female v.o.) The white zone is for immediate loading and unloading of passengers only. There is no stopping in the red zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (male v.o.) The red zone is for immediate loading and unloading of passengers. There is no stopping in the white zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (female v.o.) No. The white zone is for loading and unloading, and there is no stopping in the red zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (male v.o.) The red zone has always been for loading and unloading, and there is never stopping in a white zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (female v.o.) Don't tell me which zone is for stopping and which zone is for loading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (male v.o.) Listen, Betty. Don't start up with your white zone shit again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine enters terminal building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is approached by a religious ZEALOT #1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZEALOT #1 Hello, we'd like you to have this flower from the Religious Consciousness Church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE No, but thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrival-Departure TV monitors. Elaine approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reads: Flight 209 to Chicago - Depart Gate 89 - 7:25 p.m. Arrival monitor is goldfish swimming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She checks her watch and walks past Security Check area. CAMERA STAYS with a middle-aged couple, SHIRLEY and JACK, waiting to pass through Security Check. Behind them is si reading: WARNING, HIJACKING IS A FEDERAL OFFENSE, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHIRLEY Jack, isn't that Fred Bliffert over there in the blue turtleneck? Maybe he's on our flight to Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK Yeah, I think he is. (waves) Hey, Fred!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRED recognizes Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRED  (yelling) Hi, Jack!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A swarm of police and airport security men descend on Fre and take him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A limousine arrives. Two colorfully dressed BLACK DUDES emerge. An extra pesters them. Two HARE KRISHNA'S arrive foot and walk toward terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (female v.o.) There's just no stopping in the white zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (male v.o.) Christ, you're as bad as your mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (female v.o.) Oh, really, Vernon! Why pretend? We both know perfectly well what it is you're talking about. You want me to have an abortion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (male v.o.) It's really the only sensible thing to do. If it's done properly, therapeutically, there's no danger involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (female v.o.) Have you considered that what's inside me is a human being; that it's alive. We made love. It's us -- you and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTER (male v.o.) That isn't true. A fetus at this stage is not a human being, nor is it a person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krishnas enter terminal building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Krishnas are approached by the Religious Zealot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZEALOT #2 Hello, we'd like you to have this flower from the Church of Consciousness. Would you like to make a donation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KRISHNA  (shakes his head)  No, we gave at the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A voluptuous BLONDE saunters through the airport, clears throat loudly, and spits on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks past an ELDERLY WOMAN standing outside a men's room door. She turns and sticks her head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELDERLY WOMAN Go, O.J., go!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SECURITY CHECK LADY is watching X-ray scanner. First pict is typically filled suitcase, then another, then a chest ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man passes through metal detector archway and it BEEPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SECURITY LADY Please put your metal objects on this tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his watch, keys on the tray. Then removes his met arm and metal leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. and MRS. HAMMEN and their eight year old son, JOEY, arrive in a station wagon. They unload luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (male v.o.) The red zone is for immediate loading and unloading of passengers only. There is no stopping in the white zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. System Female v.o. weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P. A. SYSTEM (male v.o.) The red zone is for...Betty, put down that gun!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOTS and GROAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (female v.o.) The white zone is for immediate loading and unloading of passengers only. There is no stopping in the red zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hammens walk toward terminal past a BUSINESSMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUSINESSMAN Taxi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi cab skids to a stop in front of him. The Businessm gets in as the driver, TED STRIKER, drops the flag and rushes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Back in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker enters, looking around as if searching for someon People are rolling down the conveyor belt of a baggage carousel, banging into each other like luggage. The lugga is standing around the conveyor belt, waiting for the peo to come off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker, walking briskly, is approached by Zealot #3 who tries to pin a flower on his jacket. Striker keeps walkin but the Zealot is persistent. Finally, Striker slips out his jacket leaving the Zealot with the coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (v.o.) Your attention, please. Flight seven- thirty-three from Milwaukee is now arriving on the B Concourse, Gate thirty- five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight 733 taxis toward gate. A GROUND CREWMAN with red flashlights is directing plane to his right. A SECOND GROUND CREWMAN approaches as First Ground Crewman continu to direct plane to his right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUND CREWMAN #2 Hey, Joe, where's the forklift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUND CREWMAN #1 The forklift? It's over there by the baggage loader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to the left with his flashlights. Flight 733 follows flashlights and CRASHES into terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nose of Flight 733 CRASHES into terminal, scattering wait crowd. A woman tosses away her infant child as she runs o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker catches up to Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Elaine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE (surprised) Ted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER I came home early and found your note. I guess you meant for me to read it later. Elaine, I've got to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE I just don't want to go over it any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER I know things haven't been right for a long time, but it'll be different. If you'll just be patient, I can work things out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE I have been patient and I've tried to help, but you wouldn't even let me do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Don't you feel anything for me at all any more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE It takes so many things to make love last. Most of all it takes respect. And I can't live with a man I don't respect!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (to CAMERA) What a pisser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAPTAIN CLARENCE OVEUR is standing at the magazine racks. The first two sections of the display are books; the thir is girly magazines. The captions over the disВ­play are FICTION, NON-FICTION, WHACKING MATERIAL. He selects a magazine entitled "Modern Sperm" and begins to page throu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (v.o.) Captain Clarence Oveur, white courtesy phone. Captain Clarence Oveur, white courtesy phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Oveur approaches telephones and picks up a red phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPERATOR (v.o.) No, the white phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur picks up the white phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR This is Captain Oveur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPERATOR (v.o.) One moment for your call from the Mayo Clinic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (v.o.) Captain Oveur, white courtesy phone. Captain Clarence Oveur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (yelling at ceiling) I've got it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. SYSTEM (v.o.) All right. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPERATOR (v.o.) Go ahead with your call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TURNANSKY (v.o.) This is Doctor Turnansky at the Mayo Clinic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. TURNANSKY is seated at desk. Behind him are shelves filled with mayonnaise jars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TURNANSKY There's a passenger on your Chicago flight two-oh-niner, a little girl named Lisa Davis -- en route to Minneapolis. She's scheduled for a heart transplant and we'd like you to tell her mother that we found a donor an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his desk is a beaker containing a beating heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TURNANSKY We have the heart here ready for surgery and we must have the recipient on the operating table within six hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heart jumps out of the beaker, across the desk and fa off the edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TURNANSKY I want you to make sure she is kept in a reclined position and that a continuous watch is kept on her I.V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TURNANSKY (v.o.) Also, it's important that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPERATOR (v.o.) Excuse me. This is the Operator, Captain Oveur, I have an emergency call for you on line five trom a Mister Hamm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR All right. Give me Hamm on five, hold the Mayo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ambulance arrives at airplane. Attendants and MRS. DAVIS unload LISA DAVIS into wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine and Striker are walking together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Look, you'll be back in town tomorrow night. We'll have dinner -- talk it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE I won't be back. I've requested the Atlanta run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Elaine, not yet. I promise you I really can change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Then why don't you take the job that Louie Netz offered you at Boeing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g. an airline PORTER is transporting an ELDERLY COUPLE in an electric cart. They round the corner too fas and the woman falls out. Husband doesn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER You know I haven't been able to get near an airplane since the war. And even if I could, they wouldn't hire me because of my war record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Your war record? You're the only one keeping that alive. For everyone else it's ancient history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER You expect me to believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g. the Elderly Woman staggers to her feet and is immediately run over by another electric cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE It's the truth. What's hurt you the most is your record since the war. Different cities, different jobs, and not one of them shows you can accept any real responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER But if you'll just give me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE It's too late, Ted. When I get back to Chicago, I'm going to start my life all over again. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks off. Dramatic MUSIC as Striker glares with determination. The religious Zealot tries to pin a flower his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZEALOT #3 Hello, we'd like you to have this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without looking, Striker decks the Zealot with one punch. walks after Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence Oveur is in the pilot's seat. VICTOR BASTA is seated at engineer's console. There is a St. Christopher' statue on the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASTA Any word on that storm lifting over Salt Lake, Clarence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEXACO SERVICE MAN is cleaning windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Unlikely, Victor. I just reviewed the Area Report for 1609 hours through 2400 hours. That's an occluded front stalled over the Dakotas -- backed up all the way to Utah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Texaco Service Man opens hood and checks dipstick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASTA If it decides to push over into the Great Lakes it could get plenty soupy. How about the southern route, around Tulsa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR I double checked the terminal forecast and winds aloft. IFR ceilings all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur gives charge card to Texaco Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASTA Where do they top out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Well, there's some light scattered cover at twenty thousand with icing around eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASTA Looks like the original flight plan over Denver is still the best bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur signs charge form and gives it to Texaco Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Denver it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROGER MURDOCK enters. He is played by a famous athlete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK Sorry, Clarence. Latest weather report shows everything socked in from Salt Lake to Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (to Murdock) Hi, Roger. Good to have you aboard. Victor, this is Roger Murdock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASTA How do you do, Roger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Texaco Man hands receipt to Oveur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewardesses Elaine and RANDY are greeting boarding passengers including the Hammens and SISTER ANGELINA who carrying a guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARI KRISHNA #1 Do you believe those goddamn Steelers? Can you imagine blitzing on third and long with two minutes in the game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARI KRISHNA #2 Well, hell, they couldn't stay in zone coverage with Dallas running swing patterns!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK What did you think of 'Great Expectations?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHIRLEY Well, it wasn't all that I had hoped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SOLDIER and GIRL are tearfully embracing at the base of the stairs leading into the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRL Oh, Bill, I'm going to miss you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIER You promise you'll write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRL Every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AIRPORT STEWARD Better get on board, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker approaches check-in counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Can you tell me if Elaine Dickinson is on this flight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at her list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHECK-IN LADY Well, the whole flight crew has boarded. Yes. She is on board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER I'd like one ticket to Chicago. No baggage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Businessman is patiently waiting in Striker's cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHECK-IN LADY Smoking or non-smoking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Smoking, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him a smoldering ticket, and he walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker emerges and freezes in terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: agonizing over war recollections. SUPERIMPOSE ROARING fighter planes. SUPER FADES OUT. Striker musters his cour and walks toward airplane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK DUDE #l Shi',man, tha' honkey mo'fo' mess wi' my ol' lady, man I rap tha' dude upside his head, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK DUDE #2 Yeah, man, he ain't never goin' come on layin' no pig rap off you, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy is taking Striker's ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY Fourteen-B. It's halfway down on your right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Striker sits down he sees Elaine, who is unaware he is board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is handing out pillows. We HEAR A DING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "NO SMOKING EL NO A YOU SMOKO"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "FASTEN SEAT BELTS PUTANA DA SEATBELTZ"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fastens his seat belt and looks nervously out the wind The Elderly Woman next to him notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. ELDERLY Nervous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. ELDERLY First time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER No. I've been nervous lots of times. I used to be a pilot myself...during the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine approaches Mrs. Davis and Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE We'll be taking off real soon so we better fasten you in tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LISA Thank you. Oh Mother, this is so exciting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. DAVIS I know, but remember you must get some rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE That's good advice. You relax and I'll be back after we take off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILTON, an eight year old boy wearing a conservative coat and tie, fastens his seat belt and begins reading his "Business Monthly" magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees BERNICE, a seven year old girl, in the aisle and looks her up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DRAMATIC MUSIC. Engines one and two REV UP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdock and Oveur look toward left wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ENGINES three and four REV UP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdock and Oveur look toward right wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two more ENGINES REV UP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdock and Oveur look toward left wing and do a double take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two more ENGINES REV UP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdock and Oveur are confused and counting on their fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stairs are removed from airplane. The Soldier is in the o doorway waving good-bye to his tearful girlfriend at the base of the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Two-zero-niner to ground control. We are loaded and ready to taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUND CONTROL (v.o.) Roger, two-zero-niner. You are third in line for takeoff...Air Israel, taxi into position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Air Israel airplane with beard and pais, wearing a yarmulka and tallis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUND CONTROL (v.o.) Air Poland, you are cleared for takeoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crew is Jose Feliciano and look-alike for Ray Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUND CONTROL (v.o.) Taxi to runway one-niner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur moves console levers as if shifting into first gear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as 209 starts to taxi, the Soldier is leaning out the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIER Good-bye, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His girlfriend is moving along next to the plane as in typical train station good-bye scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRL Oh, good-bye, Bill! Have your picture taken as soon as you get there and send me one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she runs, she dodges posts. We HEAR the chug chug of a steam engine pulling from a station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIER I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs through crowd of people standing on side of runw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRL Don't you go getting fat or anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's running faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIER Don't worry, I won't. Okay, here -- hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses her his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRL Oh, but it's your watch. You shouldn't. You'll need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is now knocking down posts as she keeps up with the accelerating plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIER Good-bye, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRL Oh, Bill, I'll keep it. I'll keep it with me all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIER So long, darling. Good-bye. Take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRL Bill! Bill! Good-bye, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIER Good-bye, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRL Good-bye, darling. I love you. I love you, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIER Good-bye, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TRAIN WHISTLE sounds. She stops running and waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUND CONTROLLER (v.o.) Flight two-zero-niner, you are cleared for takeoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK (turning to Oveur) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur throws console lever into second gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUND CONTROLLER (v.o.) L.A. departure frequency two-point-niner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK (turning to Oveur) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASTA (to tower) Request vector...over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (turning to Basta) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUND CONTROLLER (v.o.) Flight two-zero-niner, cleared for vector three...two four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK We have clearance, Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Roger, Roger. What's our vector, Victor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur throws console lever into third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight 209 takes off, flying erratically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASTA (v.o.) Tower radioed clearance, over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (v.o.) That's Clarence Oveur...over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASTA (v.o.) Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK (v.o.) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOWER (v.o.) Roger, over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (v.o.) What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK (v.o.) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: going off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker walks to rear of plane and looks out window. He swallows a couple of pills. Randy approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY Do you feel all right, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Oh -- I haven't flown for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is handing out magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (v.o.) Good evening, this is Captain Oveur speaking. We'll be cruising at thirty-six, thousand feet, and arrival time in Chicago is ten-forty-five Central Time. The temperature there is sixty-two degrees, with a twenty percent chance of precipitation. And now here's Victor with People in the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASTA (v.o.) Thank you, Clarence. Ali McGraw announced another spin on the marriage-go-round. And who's the lucky guy? You guessed it. None other than Olympic gymnast...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine approaches Mrs. Elderly. Striker's seat is vacant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Would you like something to read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. ELDERLY Do you have anything light?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine hands her a small piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE How about this leaflet: 'Famous Jewish Sports Legends?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. ELDERLY (taking pamphlet) Yes. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine turns and is shocked to see Striker approaching hi seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Ted, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Elaine, I've got to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE You...you shouldn't have come. I don't have time now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. SCHIFF Oh, stewardess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. ELDERLY No wonder you're upset. She's lovely. And a darling figure. Supple, pouting breasts. Firm thighs. It's a shame you're not getting along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Yes, I know. Things used to be different. I remember when we first met. It was during the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker is seated at bar in a smoke-filled room. An assortment of unsavory characters are hanging around the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) I was in the Air Force, stationed in Drambuie, on the Barbary Coast. I used to hang out in the Magumba Bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shapely female legs walking on bar stop in front of Strik SLEAZY TROMBONE MUSIC. CAMERA PANS UP shapely female in tight fitting dress. She is playВ­ing the sleazy trombone music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) It was a rough place. You would count on a fight breaking out almost every night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two GIRL SCOUTS are slugging it out old Western style -- breaking tables and chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unsavory CHARACTER puts a quarter in the jukebox. One Girl Scout bashes the other against the jukebox buttons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISCO TUNE plays. Girl Scout is bashed against jukeВ­box again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girl Scout bashes again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A-12 THANK YOU"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The unsavory Character nods approvingly at selections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrons are dancing a la John Travolta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) I didn't go there that night to fall in love, I just dropped in for a couple of drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to look toward dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) But suddenly there she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine dancing with grizzly looking cutthroat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) I was captivated, entranced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) It hit me like a thunderbolt. I had to ask the guy next to me to pinch me to make sure I wasn't dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker asks the burly LONGSHOREMAN next to him to to pin him. Longshoreman gives him a look and moves away cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) I was afraid to approach her, but that night, fate was on my side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine's dancing partner is stabbed in the back and falls the grould. No one notices but Striker who eagerly fills They make a perfect disco couple. The other dancers make circle around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They begin with fancy disco steps, move on to flips and seemingly impossible acrobatics, finally ending with incredible stunts: Striker, jumping through flaming hoops and Elaine, hanging from a chandelier by her teeth and twirling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bar is closing, chairs on tables, bartender sweeping floo Elaine and Striker dancing slowly in center of room. One final Girl Scout flies into FRAME and falls in a lifeless heap at their feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER We laughed, we talked, we danced, I never wanted it to end and I guess I still don't. But enough about me. I hope this hasn't been boring for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA WIDENS to reveal Mrs. Elderly's legs dangling next him. She has hung herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER It's just that when I start to talk about Elaine, I get so carried away -- I lose all track of time -- not unlike Oliver in 'Jesus: the Man.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milton, carrying a tray with two cups of coffee, approach Bernice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILTON I happened to be passing, and I thought you might like some corfee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNICE That's very nice of you. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNICE Ah, won't you sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILTON Thank you. Cream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNICE No, thank you. I take it black. Like my men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILTON Were you vacationing in Los Angeles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNICE Well, it really wasn't a vacation. You see, I'm a teacher in the New York City school system, and I was attending a seminar on visual aids to education. Are you from L.A.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILTON No. I'm from Washington, D.C. I'm a lobbyist for the Small Businessmen's Assocation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is taking orders from a couple and their eight yea old son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Would you like to order dinner now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. HAMMEN Yes. Steak for Joey and my wife and I will have the fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY When can I see the cockpit, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. HAMMEN Well, I think that the pilots are too busy flying the plane for that, Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY Aw, gee whiz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE I tell you what, Joey. I'll talk to the Captain and see what I can arrange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY Gee! That'd be swell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine moves on to the two Black Dudes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Would you gentlemen care to order your dinners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Dudes point to their selections on the menu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK DUDE #1 'Ey ma' muh fuh wha' fo', shi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK DUDE #2 Shi' mo cain ma foh mess wi' ain?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy is taking dinner orders from Hari Krishnas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY May I take your dinner order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARI KRISHNA #1 No, thank you, we brought our own vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARI KRISHNA #2 But we would like some hot water for our tea, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARI KRISHNA #1 Did you catch the jugs on that broad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is replacing a magazine and catches sight of Strik

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boring another passenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves into the alcove and begins to pour coffee. CAME MOVES INTO CLOSEUP of Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker and Elaine are running. She falls down at the water's edge, exhausted. Striker drops to his knees and t embrace passionately. A huge wave washes over them coveri them completely. When the wave recedes, they're still loc in the same embrace. They are covered with seaweed. Fish flopping around in the sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Oh, Ted, I never knew I could be so happy. These past few months have been wonderful. Tomorrow why don't we drive up the coast to that little seafood place and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER My orders came through. My squadron ships out tomorrow. I'll be leading a very important mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Oh, Ted, please be careful. I worry about you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER I love you, Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace. Another huge wave washes in and covers them completely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine comes back to reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In level flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUND CONTROL (v.o.) Flight two-zero-niner, this is Denver Flight Control. You're approaching some rough weather. Please climb to forty-two thousand feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Roger, Denver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a KNOCK on the cockpit door. Elaine and Joey ent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE We have a visitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE This is Captain Oveur. Mister Murdock and Mister Johnson. This is Joey Hammen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK Come on up here. You can see better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Joey, here's something we give our special visitors. Would you like to have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives Joey a small toy airplane and puts his arm aroun him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY Thank you. Thanks a lot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Have you ever been in a cockpit before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY No, sir. I've never been up in a plane before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Have you ever seen a grown man naked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK Do you want me to check the weather, Clarence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (looking at Joey) No, why don't you take care ot it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE We'd better get back now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Joey can stay up here for a while if he'd like to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY Could I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Okay, if you don't get in the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine exits. Murdock picks up phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK Flight two-zero-niner to Denver radio. Climbing to cruise at forty-two thousand. Will report again over Lincoln. Over and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey has been paying very close attention to Murdock, and suddenly recognizes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY Wait a minute. I know you. You're Kareem Abdul Jabbar. You play basketball for the Los Angeles Lakers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK I'm sorry, son, but you must have me confused with someone else. My name is Roger Murdock. I'm the co-pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Basta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK Ah, Victor, why don't you get the coordinates on the altitude vector and find out the ratio of direct velocity over engine speed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor is puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY You are Kareem. I've seen you play. My Dad's got season tickets!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK I think you should go back to your seat now, Joey. Right, Clarence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR No, he's not bothering anyone. Let him stay up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK All right. But just remember, my name is Roger Murdock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to his nametag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK I'm an airline pilot. (to Oveur) Ah, Clarence, according to my calculations, with this tailwind we ought to be able to make up an additional fifteen minutes over the Rockies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY I think you're the greatest. But my Dad says you don't work hard enough on defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK (into microphone) Denver Control, this is Flight two-zero- niner intersecting Victor Airway seven- niner-niner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY ...and that lots of times you don't even run down court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK We are turning left to a heading of zero- niner-niner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY ...and that you don't really try, except during the playoffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK The hell I don't! I'm out there busting my buns every night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdock realizes he has given himself away. He quickly lo to see if Oveur is listening. Oveur is busy checking instruments. Murdock grabs Joey by the collar and whisper angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK Listen, kid, I've been hearing that crap ever since I was at UCLA. Tell your old man to drag Unseld and Lanier up and down the court for forty-eight minutes. (into mike) Ah...Denver Control, this is Flight two- zero-niner continuing on a heading two- niner-niner...niner, ah...niner...niner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is seated next to Striker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Elaine, just hear me out. I know things haven't been right for a long time. But it will be different...like it was in the beginning. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE I remember everything. All I have are memories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft MUSIC begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Mostly I remember...the nights when we were together. I remember how you used to hold me...and how I used to sit on your face and wriggle...and then afterwards how we'd watch until the sun came up. When it did, it was almost like...like each new day was created...only for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER That's the way I've always wanted it to be, Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE But it won't be. Not as long as you insist on living in the past!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine leaves, teary-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fighter plane diving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SQUADRON LEADER (v.o.) You're too low, Ted! You're too low!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fighter plane CRASHES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign in front reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PENTATHOL AVAILABLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Charge, Visa, Carte Blanche

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker is lying in bed painting a canvas. Elaine is seat at bedside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE You got a telegram from headВ­quarters today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Headquarters!? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE It's a big building where the generals meet. But that's not important right now. They've cleared you of any blame for what happened on that raid. Isn't that good news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A surreal image of a soldier contorted like a pretzel clutching a machine gun in one hand and a crying infant i the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER Is it? Because of my mistake six men didn't return from that raid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Seven. Lieutenant Zipp died this morning. Ted, Doctor Sandler says you'll be out in a week. Isn't that wonderful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g., a doctor in a white lab coat is attending a patient. When he turns around WE SEE he is wearing an STP insignia on his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER I wish I could say the same for George Zipp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Be patient, Ted. No one expects you to get over this immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker is despondent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SGT. McCOBB (o.s.) Hey, Striker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. HOSPITAL - ANGLE - SGT. McCOBB - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is posing for Striker's painting, contorted like a pretzel, holding a machine gun in one hand and crying bab in the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SGT. McCOBB How about a break? I'm getting tired!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER All right. Take five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCobb untangles himself and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE I found a wonderful apartment for us. It's got a brick fireplace and a cute little bedroom with mirrors on the ceiling. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAPTAIN GELINE (o.s.) I'm off course. Red Leader!!! Look out!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER That's Captain Geline. He thinks he's a pilot, still fighting the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Geline agonizing and making bombing and machine g noises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIEUTENANT HURWITZ (o.s.) Groan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE What's his problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER That's Lieutennt Hurwitz. Severe shell shock. He thinks he's Ethel Merman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strapped to the bed is ETHEL MERMAN singing "EVERYTHING'S COMING UP ROSES." She breaks loose from the straps for a grand finale. Two attendants attempt to restrain her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY Excuse me, sir. Would you like some coffee before we serve dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER No. No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy moves on to the Hammens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY Would either of you like another cup of coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. HAMMEN I will, but Jim won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. HAMMEN Yes, I think I will have another cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA ZOOMS to CLOSEUP of Mrs. Hammen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. HAMMEN'S THOUGHTS (v.o.) Jim never has a second cup of coffee at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy approaches Sister Angelina. The guitar is on the se next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY Excuse me, Sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SISTER ANGELINA Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY There's a little girl on board who's ill and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SISTER ANGELINA Oh yes, I saw. Poor child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY Could I borrow your guitar? I thought I might be able to cheer her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SISTER ANGELINA Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy takes the guitar and walks down the aisle. The guit clonks people on the back of the head. Randy approaches Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY Is it all right if I talk to your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. DAVIS Oh, I think that would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY (to Lisa, who is reading) Hi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LISA Hi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY I'm Randy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LISA I'm Lisa. Oh, you have a guitar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY I thought maybe you'd like to hear a song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LISA Oh, I'd love to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY Okay, this is one of my favorites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy is sitting on the edge of the gurney as she strums three opening chords.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY (strumming and singing in ballad tempo) 'I've traveled the banks of the River Jordan, to find where it flows to the sea.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewardesses and passengers notice the singer and peer around corners and over seat backs. A man's head peers upside down from the TOP OF THE FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY 'I looked in the eyes of the cold and the hungry and saw that I was looking at me.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As singing continues, Shirley and Jack look at each other with saccherine smiles, the Hammens do the same, then the Krishnas, then the Black Dudes. Finally, everyone is smil sweetly at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdock and Oveur smile sweetly at each other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY (singing and playing the guitar) 'And I wanted to know if life had a purpose, and what it all means in the end. In the silence I listened to the voices inside me, and they told me again and again.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tempo Jumps to rock pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY 'There is only one river. There is only one sea.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy, in her growing enthusiasm, swings her guitar, knocking the I.V. connection tube from Lisa's arm. The I. squirts, and Lisa turns pale and hollowВ­cheeked. No one notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY 'And it flows through you, and it flows through me. There is only one people, we are one and the same.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa manages to reconnect her I.V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY (still singing) 'We are all one spirit, one name. We are the Father, we are the son.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy again knocks I.V. from Lisa's arm with guitar as th passengers start to get into the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY 'In the Dawn of Creation. We are one.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Davis rushes to reconnect Lisa's I.V. Lisa doesn't react. Mrs. Davis pounds Lisa's chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY & PASSENGERS 'We are only one people, we are one and the same.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lisa revives, Randy swings her guitar and clonks Mrs. Davis on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY & PASSENGERS 'We are all one spirit on Earth, one name.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY & PASSENGERS (v.o.) 'We are the Father, we are the son, and in the Dawn of Creation we are one.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine enters with dinners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Hey, we've been waiting for you. A little bit late tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Who wants to be first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK Go ahead, Clarence, I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur removes his headset, Elaine puts tray down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE How's the weather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK Not so good. We've got some heavy stuff ahead of us. It might get rough again unless we can climb on top. But our airspeed is holding steady at six hundred ten knots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE That's great. By the way, Joey Hammen asked me if you would autograph this basketball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdock autographs it reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A JAPANESE GENERAL, dressed in World War II uniform, is n seated next to Striker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER After the war, I just wanted to get as far away from things as possible. So Elaine and I joined the Peace Corps. We were assigned to an isolated tribe, the Molombos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker and Elaine are being escorted to the chief's hut two GUARDS. We hear Jungle Animal SOUNDS. The chief is standing in front of his hut surrounded by several TRIBES who are making the jungle animal sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) They had never seen Americans before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Striker and Elaine arrive, the CHIEF holds up his ha and the sounds stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) At first, they didn't know what to think of us; but soon we gained their trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief extends his right hand for conventional handsha Striker shows him power grip. When the Chief is pleased, Striker gives him five. The Chief pauses then decks Strik

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) It really was a challenge during the year introducing them to our Western culture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is having a Supperware party for native women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Also, Supperware products are ideal for storing leftovers to help stretch your food dollar. This two quart "Seals-M-Rite" container with a special "Close-M-Tite" lid keeps hotdog buns fresh for days and prevents sugared cereals from sticking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She scoops a ladle of corn mush from a carved wooden bowl into a Supperware container.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Meat and dairy products are protected against unwanted refrigerator odors when sealed in this non-slip pastel colored "Freez-o-leer".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she burps the lid, the Supperware makes a human burp SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker nailing crude basketball rim and net to tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) You must understand that these people had been completely isolated from civilization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker demonstrates a two-handed set shot to natives. He misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) No one had ever outlined a physical fitness program for them and they had no athletic equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Native examines basketball for first time. After two slow dribbles, he gracefully feints lefts, then, dribbling through his legs, sinks a two-hand, over-the-head, revers dunk shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) We also emphasized nutrition and taught them to watch their diets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another native hits a long jump shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) The exercise improved their physical fitness and condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One shot after another swishes through the basketball rim

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) My working with them seemed to reinforce our objectives of group cooperation and controlled-competitive activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker approaches Elaine who is standing on the sideline As they talk, the natives are passing the ball around and shooting baskets Harlem Globetrotter fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER I think they're getting the hang of it! When we re-enlist I'll teach them baseball!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Ted, I don't want to stay here. It's time for us to go back home -- to the plans we made before the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER A lot of people made plans before the war. Like George Zipp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine walks away, dejectedly. CAMERA STAYS with Striker he pours Gator-Ade into a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER (v.o.) I guess it was at that moment that I first realized Elaine had doubts about our relationship. And that as much as anything else led to my drinking problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker has a problem drinking. He raises his glass of Gator-Ade, then suddenly pours it on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER We did come back to the States. I tried a number of jobs...Well, I could go on for hours, but I'd probably start to bore you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Japanese General is kneeling on the seat committing H Kari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKER You know, I really couldn't blame Elaine. She wanted a career. I was offered a job at Boeing but I couldn't bring myself to take it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The businessman waiting in Striker's cab checks his watch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER and lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley is ill and holding her stomach in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHIRLEY Oh, I can't stand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHIRLEY My, stomach. I haven't felt this awful since we saw that Lina Wertmuller film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE I'll see if I can find some Dramamine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHIRLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Captain, one of the women passengers is very sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey enters to retrieve basketball. Murdock is wearing goggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Airsick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE I think so, but I've never seen it so acute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Find out if there's a doctor on board, as quietly as you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur hangs up phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Joey, have you ever been in a Turkish prison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. HAMMEN (nauseous) Oooh, I shouldn't have had that second cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs for motion sickness bag. CAMERA ZOOMS to CLOSEUP Mrs. Hammen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. HAMMEN'S THOUGHTS (v.o.) Jim never vomits at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER and lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is speaking to couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE I'm sorry I had to wake you. I'm just looking for a doctor. There's nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Middle-aged lady, MRS. YAFFE, having overheard this conversation, beckons to Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. YAFFE Stewardess, I think the man next to me is a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAN next to her is wearing a surgical cap with mask. Hanging around his neck is a stethoscope. He's sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Sir. Excuse me, sir. I'm sorry to have to wake you. Are you a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE We have some passengers who are very sick. Could you come and take a look at them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK Yes. Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rumack picks up bag and exits with Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rumack and Elaine enter. Rumack stoops over to Shirley, a surgical instrument is slapped into his hand from o.s. He pokes her stomach with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK Pain there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She winces and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK May I see your tongue, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sticks her tongue out. Rumack pulls on it until it is obviously too long. He continues to pull, and the tongue becomes multi-colored magician's scarves. Then he pulls o a bouquet of flowers followed by a white dove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK I'll be back in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rumack takes Elaine aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK You'd better tell the Captain. We've got to land as soon as we can. This woman has to be gotten to a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE A hospital? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK It's a big building with patients. But that's not important right now. Tell the Captain I must speak to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (into mike) Thank you, Omaha. Two-zero-niner out. (to Basta) Victor, we're running into a heavy storm, can you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur turns to see Basta slumped over the console.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dramatic MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Victor! Roger, take over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur lifts Basta onto ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER and lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdock, flying the plane alone, wipes his brow and appea ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK Captain, how soon can we land?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR I can't tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. ROMACK You can tell me. I'm a doctor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR No. I mean I'm just not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK Can't you take a guess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Well...not for another two hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK You can't take a guess for another two hours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR No, I mean we can't land for another two hours. Fog has closed down everything this side of the mountains. We've got to go through to Chicago!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the plane rocks violently. Rumack and Oveur los balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER and lightning -- plane is flying erratically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdock, unconscious, is slumped over controls. Oveur and Rumack burst into cockpit. Oveur gets into pilot's seat. Elaine enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (excitedly) Get him out of there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Altitude is fluctuating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur struggles with controls. They extricate Murdock fro behind the wheel. He is wearing shorts, kneepads, and basketball shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: climbing and diving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers are being tossed about. A woman, applying lipstick, smears it over her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- cigarette with line slashed through, and couple copulating with line slashed through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy loses her balance and shoves dinner into a passenge face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: struggling with controls, finally regains level flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER and lightning -- plane levels off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The St. Christopher statue is holding a motion discomtort bag to its mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR What is it, Doctor? What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK I'm not sure. I haven't seen anything like this since the Lina Wertmuller Film Festival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rumack and Elaine are now standing face-to-face. Oveur, i the f.g., is at controls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK What was it we had for dinner tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Well, we had a choice. Steak or fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK Yes, yes, I remember. I had lasagna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK What did he have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE He had fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy enters cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY We have two more sick people, and the rest of the passengers are worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR I'll take care of the passengers. Elaine, find out what the two sick people had for dinner. (into P.A.) This is Captain Oveur speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers are listening to P.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (v.o.) It's been a little bumpy up here but we'll be past it in a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy and Elaine drag Murodck and Basta down center aisle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (v.o.) A couple points of interest: we're just now passing over the Hoover Dam and later on, our course will take us just south of the Grand Canyon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR Meanwhile, relax and enjoy the rest of your flight. Okay? Okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up phone and turns to Rumack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR That should do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolute pandemonium. Passengers are yelling, screaming, tearing their hair out, climbing about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (into microphone) Chicago, this is flight two-zero-niner. We're in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS OUT to reveal DISPATCHER typing Oveur's message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (v.o.) We've got to have all altitudes below us cleared and priority approach and landing in Chicago. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISPATCHER We read you. Stand by, two-zero-niner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he tries to remove paper from typewriter, it rips in half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER and lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy approaches Hammens. Mr. Hammen is sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. HAMMEN Oh, Stewardess. My husband is very sick. Can you do something, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY Well, the doctor will be with you in just a moment. One thing: do you know what he had for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. HAMMEN Yes, of course. We both had fish. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY Oh, it's nothing to be alarmed about. We'll get back to you very quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to walk toward CAMERA with horrified expression

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine enters, turns to face Rumack. Oveur is at controls f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Doctor Rumack, Mister Hammen ate fish. And Randy says there are five more cases, and they ate fish, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK Let's see now. The co-pilot had fish. What did the navigator eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE He had fish, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur is picking up on the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK All right, now we know what we're up against. Every passenger on this plane who ate fish for dinner will become violently ill within the next half hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur looks down at his dinner tray and sees skeleton of fish he just ate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Just how serious is it, doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK Extremely serious. It starts with a slight fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur experiences what the doctor is describing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK Then a dryness in the throat. As the virus penetrates the red blood cells the victim becomes dizzy and begins to experience a rash and itching. From there the poison works its way into the central nervous system causing severe muscle spasms, followed by the inevitable drooling. At this point, the entire digestive system is rendered useless, causing the complete collapse of the lower bowels, accompanied by uncontrollable flatulence...until finally the poor bastard is reduced to a quivering, wasted piece of jelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur passes out and pitches forward onto the controls. Rumack and Elaine lose balance as plane dives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER and lightning as plane is diving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers are being tossed about. A woman, applying roug smears it all over her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wiggling. CAMERA PANS UP to braless woman whose breasts a wiggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they finally untangle Oveur from the wheel, he gains semi-consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (gasping) Turn...on...automatic pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oveur passes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Uh, automatic pilot...automatic pilot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is frantically searching for automatic pilot button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE There it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine's hand tenuously reaches for and turns switch to "ON".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of rushing air as instantly inflatable balloon pilo takes shape in seat with hands on wheel. His uniform and are painted on, and he has an alert "leave the driving to us" expression on his face. The plane immediately regains level flight, and Elaine and Rumack sigh in relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK I'll get back to the passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rumack exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY (v.o.) (over radio) Come in two-zero-niner. This is Chicago. Flight two-zero-niner, come in, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine picks up mike while still standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE This is Elaine Dickinson. I'm the stewardess. Captain Oveur is passed out on the floor, and we've lost the co-pilot and navigator, too. We're in terrible trouble. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (o.s.) Groan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY (v.o.) Elaine! Roger, Roger! I read you. This is Steve McCroskey at Chicago Air Control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Hi, Steve!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY (v.o.) Now listen carefully. Is the automatic pilot on? Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Yes. Yes, it is. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVEUR (o.s.) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY (v.o.) Very good. Now, Elaine, where are you? Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE I'm standing over Oveur. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY (into mike) All right, Elaine. Just hold on. We'll be back to you in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal dispatch is a beehive of activity. The Chief Dispatcher, STEVE McCROSKEY, is barki orders to AIR CONTROLLER #1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY Hold all takeoffs. I don't want another plane in the air. When the 508 reports, bring it straight in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air Controller #1 exits quickly. McCroskey picks up phone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY Put out a general bulletin to suspend all meal service on flights out of Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up phone and talks to AIR CONTROLLER #2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY Tell all dispatchers to remain at their posts. It's going to be a long night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air Controller #2 exits. McCroskey notices he is out of coffee and turns to AIR CONTROLLER HINSHAW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY And how about some coffee, Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HINSHAW No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AIR CONTROLLER #3 enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY I want the weather on every landing field on this side of the Rockies, no matter what the size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air Controller #3 exits. AIR CONTROLLER #4 enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air Controller #4 exits. AIR CONTROLLER #5 enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY Any place where there's a chance to land this plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air Controller #5 exits. SIAMESE TWINS enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY Stan, go upstairs to the tower and get a runway diagram. Terry, check down on the field for emergency equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siamese Twins leave. In the b.g. we see them trying to wa in opposite directions. Air Controller #1 enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AIR CONTROLLER #1 Chief, there's fog down to the deck everywhere east of the Rockies. There's no possible place they can land. They'll have to come through to Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY Looks like I picked the wrong week to quit smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lights up a cigarette. McCroskey walks toward a table leans on his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY I want the best available man on this. A man who knows this plane inside and out and won't crack under pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HINSHAW How about Sal Mineo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY Get me Rex Kramer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightning and THUNDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is in the pilot's seat and the inflated automatic pilot is in co-pilot's seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY (v.o.) Now, Elaine, right next to the throttle is the air speed gauge. What speed does it indicate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Three hundred twenty miles per hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see, but Elaine does not notice, the automatic pilot v slowly beginning to deflate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY (v.o.) Good. Now check your altitude. That's the dial just below and to the right of the air speed indicator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Thirty-five thousand feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Altitude is dropping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE No, wait. Now it says thirty-four thousand feet. It's dropping! It's dropping fast! Why is it doing that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now the automatic pilot is really slumped over as it i quite deflated. It is staring at her with a half smile. Elaine notices it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Oh, my God! The automatic pilot! It's deflating!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY (v.o.) All right, Elaine, don't worry. We have an auxiliary inflation system. Just follow my instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Okay, but please hurry! We're dropping fast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers are being tossed about. Rumack is examining a female patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK What the hell's going on up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rumack starts toward cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY (v.o.) Now, Elaine, don't panic. On the belt line of the automatie pilot there is a hollow tube. Can you see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Yes. Yes, I can see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCROSKEY (v.o.) Good. Now that's the manual inflation nozzle. Pull it out and blow it up like a balloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine kneels over automatic pilot's crotch, puts tube in her mouth and blows. Automatic pilot inflates. Rumack bur into cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back of automatic pilot with Elaine kneeling over its crotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rumack slams the door in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with a big smile on its face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers are relieved as plane regains level flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine and automatic pilot are relaxed in their seats. Bo are smoking cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER and lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rumack enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK Elaine, you're a member of this crew. Can you face some unpleasant facts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK All right. Unless I can get all these people to a hospital quickly, I can't even be sure of saving their lives. Now, is there anyone else on board who can land this plane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striker, struggling with drinking problem, pours drink between his cheek and ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE No. No one that I know of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RUMACK I think you ought to know what our chances are. The life of everyone on board depends on just one thing: finding someone back there who not only can fly this plane, but who didn't have fish for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA ZOOMS into CLOSEUP of Elaine's face as she realize the severity of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER and lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers are listening to P.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE (v.o.) Ladies and gentlemen, this is your stewardess speaking. We regret any inconvenience the sudden cabin movement might have caused.
